 Obviously our loquacious lagomorph, a devout Darwin-denier, is terminally confused about two distinct forms of adaptation in biology. The first is organismal adaptation in response to environmental cues. Examples include, as I have mentioned before, changes in fur colour or density with the season, or behavioural changes in response to seasonal food availability. Not all species have equal abilities to adapt to environmental changes, and many have adapted to a single environment and fare poorly if it changes beyond fairly narrow parameters. A single genome (and epigenome) can encode all the necessary information for adaptive responses to an environment.
 
 The other important form of adaptation is species adaptation, where owing to genetic evolution, new traits are adapted from old ones, for example, wings from limbs. This is no mere epigenetic change like fur colour, but a profound change in how genes are expressed. It can't easily be switched on and off by altering the epigenetic environment, except in unusual cases. Chicken embryos, for example, can be induced to grow teeth-like structures... the genes to do this are still there, though they evidently have other functions as well, but it takes considerable artificial tissue manipulation to switch them on.
 
 What really baffles me is why anyone should think this is somehow inconsistent with Darwinian theory. I realise our loquacious lagomorph doesn't read anything he thinks will be disagreeable, so he never learns anything new, but Darwinian theory isn't irrevocably tied to any particular model of how genes control development. Indeed, Darwin thought of it before anyone had heard of genes.
 
 Our ideas of how genes control development have evolved considerably over the last few years -- not that lagomorph has a clue about them -- but there is nothing about them that disproves Darwinian theory, or, come to that, supports Lamarck. Maybe there is a back door somewhere in epigenetics for Lamarckian mechanisms of inheriting acquired characteristics, but I haven't seen a case for it yet. The only way one can claim, as our lagomorph does, that epigenetics disproves "Darwinism" is to have a totally clueless idea of what "Darwinism" is.

 The real key lies, as biologists have suspected for many decades and known for some 20 years or so, in how and when they are expressed, which is controlled by other associated DNA sequences, and those vary in number and arrangement from species to species. For example, it's pretty much the same genes that build a penguin's flipper as a bat's wing, or a human arm or leg.  I wouldn't reject non-covalent, or non-DNA, epigenetic modification out of hand as non-heritable, however. Remember, what we are talking about here is basins of stability. It just depends on how many different steady state configurations of epigenetic environments one genome can support.
 
 After all, every genome supports up to hundreds of different cell types, depending on the organism, each with its own epigenetic environment. Of course, they all depend on their unique genome, but that doesn't mean there isn't wiggle room.
